review.title: Semantic Integration & Single-Site Opening of Multiple Governmental Data Sources
review.abstract: In many cases, government data is still "locked" in several "data silos", even within the boundaries of a single (inter-)national public organization with disparate and distributed organizational units and departments spread across multiple sites. Opening data and enabling its unified querying from a single site in an efficient and effective way is a semantic application integration and open government data challenge. This paper describes how NARA is using Semantic Web technology to implement an application integration approach within the boundaries of its organization via opening and querying multiple governmental data sources from a single site. The generic approach proposed, namely S3-AI, provides support to answering unified, ontology-mediated, federated queries to data produced and exploited by disparate applications, while these are being located in different organizational sites. S3-AI preserves ownership, autonomy and independency of applications and data. The paper extensively demonstrates S3-AI, using the D2RQ and Fuseki technologies, for addressing the needs of a governmental "IT helpdesk support" case.

sections.heading: 2 Application Integration Setting and Requirements
sections.text: NARA is a European administrative authority located in the North Aegean Sea, in five main locations, each with its own organisational unit. Each of the five organisational units is a formal member of NARA, i.e. it must make its own administrative requirements. NARA is a new formal organisation, formed following a Greek reform initiative in 2010, bringing together the three former prefectures in the North Aegean Sea.

sections.heading: 4.1 D2RQ and Fuseki technologies
sections.text: D2RQ is an easy-to-install and use open source software platform for accessing relational databases as virtual (read-only) RDF graphs. It provides RDF-based access to the contents of a relational database without having to replicate it into an RDF memory, thereby avoiding additional implementation and maintenance efforts. Among other things, it is possible to remotely access RDF descriptions of individual entities in the database via the SPARQL protocol (SPARQL endpoint) by dereferencing their URIs (Linked Data provides RDF shortcuts as an alternative to registered discovery mechanisms for the Semantic Web), and c) display contents in HTML (for support for writing and debugging mappings).

sections.heading: 7 Discussion
sections.text: The S3-AI approach is not limited to the number of applications / data sources that need to be integrated, depending on the scalability of the semantic web technologies used for a particular application. It is possible to adapt the S3-AI approach simply by replacing each technological component with a more scalable one, as the new technology provides at least the functionality shown in the S3-AI implementation, and the recommendation is to use the technologies used in this case (mainly due to their simplicity, open source nature and adaptability).

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: The proposed approach was implemented using the free open source software D2RQ and Fuseki and used in the e-government area within the "eGov IT Helpdesk Support" case. Furthermore, the benefits of the approach and the lessons learned from its initial deployment can be discussed. We firmly believe that the approach is noticeable for its simplicity, low cost, low maintenance and highly adaptable architecture. In addition, it can be used to integrate "living" and evolving data from multiple sources without the need to forgo original applications and data storage if certain guidelines and recommendations discussed in the paper are followed. Future plans concern the use of S3-AI in other areas where evolving data from different economical applications must be integrated, resulting in further refinements of the approach and further recommendations for its use in different contexts that are open to multiple data sources beyond different government requirements.
